description: Channel Islands National Park encompasses five remarkable islands and their ocean environment, preserving and protecting a wealth of natural and cultural resources. Isolation over thousands of years has created unique animals, plants, and archeological resources found nowhere else on Earth and helped preserve a place where visitors can experience coastal southern California as it once was.
directionsInfo: While the mainland visitor center in Ventura is readily accessible by car or public transportation, the islands are only accessible by park concessionaire boats and planes or private boat. Advanced planning is highly recommended.

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day. Services and facilities have separate hours. Please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Channel Islands National Park

images.title: Inspiration Point by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Steep, rugged ocean cliffs extending in an island chain.
images.caption: Inspiration Point, Anacapa Island: One of the most spectacular views in the park can be found from Inspiration Point. Looking to the west, one may see Middle and West Anacapa, with Santa Cruz Island in the distance.

images.title: Arch Point by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Yellow flowers in foreground extending out along a rocky coastline to a natural arch.
images.caption: Arch Point, Santa Barbara Island: With winter rains, the coreopsis emerges from summer's dormancy with light green foliage and bright yellow daisy-like flowers

images.title: Torrey Pines by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Pine tree high on a ridge overlooking a bay with blue water and white sand beach.
images.caption: Torrey Pines, Santa Rosa Island: Torrey pines occur naturally in only two locations throughout the world--on the cool, fog drenched northeastern slopes of Bechers Bay and just north of San Diego.

images.title: Point Bennet by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Brown seals and sea lions on white sand beach with blue water and partly cloudy sky.
images.caption: Point Bennet, San Miguel Island: One of the greatest concentrations of wildlife in the world occurs on San Miguel with over 100,000 pinnipeds gathering to breed, pup, and rest.

images.title: Island Fox by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Rust and grey colored fox in green grass.
images.caption: Island Fox, Santa Cruz Island: Thousands of years of isolation in a unique island environment has resulted in the development of the endemic island fox, a dwarf form of the mainland gray fox.

weatherInfo: In general, the islands have a Mediterranean climate year-round. Temperatures are relatively stable, with highs averaging in the mid-60s (Â°F) and lows in the low-50s. However, there are seasonal differences that visitors should take into consideration when visiting the park. In addition, visitors also should be aware that ocean and weather conditions vary considerably from day-to-day and island-to-island. For more information visit: http://www.nps.gov/chis/planyourvisit/weather.htm

description: In this below-sea-level basin, steady drought and record summer heat make Death Valley a land of extremes. Yet, each extreme has a striking contrast. Towering peaks are frosted with winter snow. Rare rainstorms bring vast fields of wildflowers. Lush oases harbor tiny fish and refuge for wildlife and humans. Despite its morbid name, a great diversity of life thrives in Death Valley.

entranceFees.description: This permit allows all persons traveling with the permit holder in one single private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van/RV/aircraft) to leave and re-enter the park as many times as they wish during the 7-day period from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This permit allows persons traveling on one motorcycle to leave and re-enter the park as many times as they wish during the 7-day period from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This permit allows a single individual traveling on foot or individuals traveling on one bicycle to leave and re-enter the park as many times as they wish during the 7-day period from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description:
1 - 6 Passenger Vehicle: $25 + $10 per person.

In addition to the entrance fees listed below, additional permits are required for commercial groups, special park uses (weddings, memorialization, group events, etc.), commercial film and photography, research, and more.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description:
1 - 6 Passenger Vehicle: $25 + $10 per person

In addition to the entrance fees listed below, additional permits are required for commercial groups, special park uses (weddings, memorialization, group events, etc.), commercial film and photography, research, and more.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description:
7 - 15 Passenger Vehicle: $75

In addition to the entrance fees listed below, additional permits are required for commercial groups, special park uses (weddings, memorialization, group events, etc.), commercial film and photography, research, and more.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description:
16 - 25 Passenger Vehicle: $100

In addition to the entrance fees listed below, additional permits are required for commercial groups, special park uses (weddings, memorialization, group events, etc.), commercial film and photography, research, and more.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description:
26 + Passenger Vehicle: $200

In addition to the entrance fees listed below, additional permits are required for commercial groups, special park uses (weddings, memorialization, group events, etc.), commercial film and photography, research, and more.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial Groups (e.g., Scout groups, church groups, etc.) entering in a vehicle with a capacity of 16 persons or more are charged per-person for each person on board, not to exceed $200.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: National Park Service regulations allow school groups and other approved national and international academic institutions to obtain a waiver of Park entrance fees, provided that visit is for educational or scientific purposes, and the resources or facilities that the group intends to use, support those purposes. Submit your waiver through the link below at least one month prior to your visit.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entrancePasses.description: This pass allows all persons traveling with the pass holder in one single private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) or those on a motorcycle to leave and re-enter the park as many times as they wish for 12 months from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

directionsInfo: There are multiple entrances to the park. Click below to learn the best ways to travel to Death Valley.

operatingHours.description: The park is open daily all year. The remnants of Hurricane Hilary triggered flash floods that damaged all park roads on August 20, 2023. Many roads remain closed.
operatingHours.name: Death Valley National Park

images.title: Sunset from Zabriskie Point
images.altText: badlands bathed in pale pink and orange light from the setting sun
images.caption: The warm light of sunset covers the badlands at Zabriskie Point.

images.title: Zabriskie Point
images.altText: Morning light on the badlands below Zabriskie Point.
images.caption: Zabriskie Point is a popular place to view sunrise over the badlands.

images.title: Storm over the Salt Flats
images.altText: white salt flats with dark gray clouds
images.caption: Badwater Basin is the lowest point in North America at -282 feet.

images.title: Sunset at Dantes View
images.altText: a sunset overlooking a valley filled with white salt
images.caption: A mile above the salt flats in the valley below, Dantes View provides breathtaking vistas.

images.title: Lupine and Tortoiseshell Butterfly
images.altText: pink lupine flowers with an orange and black butterfly
images.caption: Higher elevations provide a respite from the heat in this alpine ecosystem.

images.title: Wildrose Charcoal Kilns
images.altText: nine 25 foot tall rock beehive structures
images.caption: Nearly a century and a half old, these are some of the best preserved kilns in the western U.S.

images.title: A rare superbloom of Desert Gold.
images.altText: a field of yellow flowers with a mountain
images.caption: About once a decade, rains at the right times can lead to a rare superbloom!

images.title: Hottest Place on Earth
images.altText: thermometer reading 130 f 54 c
images.caption: Summers are infamously hot, as for 6 months of the year temperatures above 120 degrees are regularly recorded.

images.title: Winding canyons await
images.altText: polished walls of a narrow canyon
images.caption: There are numerous canyons to explore across this vast park.

weatherInfo: SPRING is the most popular time to visit Death Valley. Warm and sunny days with the possibility of spring wildflowers is a big attraction. SUMMER starts early in Death Valley. By May the valley can be scorching hot. AUTUMN arrives in late October, with warm but pleasant temperatures and generally clear skies. WINTER has cool days, chilly nights and rarely, rainstorms. With snow capping the high peaks and low angled winter light, this season is especially beautiful for exploring the valley.

description: Two distinct desert ecosystems, the Mojave and the Colorado, come together in Joshua Tree National Park. A fascinating variety of plants and animals make their homes in a land sculpted by strong winds and occasional torrents of rain. Dark night skies, a rich cultural history, and surreal geologic features add to the wonder of this vast wilderness in southern California. Come explore for yourself!

entranceFees.description: 7-day vehicle permit, admitting the passengers of a single, non-commercial vehicle on the day of purchase and for the next six days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: 7-day entrance permit, per motorcycle.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: 7-day entrance fee, per person on foot or bike.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for 12 months from the month of purchase. It covers the entrance fee to Joshua Tree National Park for the pass signee and accompanying passengers entering in a single, non-commercial vehicle. Joshua Tree Annual Passes are available at park entrance stations and visitor centers.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

directionsInfo: From I-10, take exit 117 for CA Hwy 62 toward 29 Palms/Yucca Valley. This will allow you to access the West Entrance, the North Entrance, Black Rock, and Indian Cove. Take exit 168 off I-10 to come in at the park's South Entrance.

operatingHours.description: Joshua Tree National Park is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year. Visitation increases as temperatures moderate in the fall, peaks during the spring wildflower season, and diminishes during the heat of summer. Some areas of the park are designated for day use only. Visitor centers keep separate hours; please see descriptions.
operatingHours.name: Joshua Tree National Park

images.title: Quail Springs Area at Sunset
images.altText: The sky turns hues of pink and purple over a field of Joshua trees.
images.caption: Quail Springs area at sunset

images.title: Hidden Valley Hiker
images.altText: hiker looks over Hidden Valley
images.caption: Scrambling to the top of boulders in Joshua Tree can get you a great view.

images.title: Historic Keys Ranch
images.altText: an historic wood house seen through the missing windshield of an old, rusty vehicle
images.caption: The historic Keys Ranch can be visited only on a ranger-guided tour.

images.title: Lost Horse Valley
images.altText: Joshua trees grow on a flat plain with boulder outcrops and mountains in the distance
images.caption: Take in views of the park's iconic Joshua trees and rock outcrops in Lost Horse Valley.

images.title: Joshua Tree Junior Ranger
images.altText: a little girl smiles while wearing a Jr. Ranger hat and badge
images.caption: Kids of all ages can take part in Joshua Tree National Park's Junior Ranger program.

images.title: Joshua Tree Sunset
images.altText: a fiery sky behind the silhouette of a Joshua tree
images.caption: The wide-open desert of Joshua Tree National Park makes for stunning sunsets.

images.title: Jumbo Rocks at Sunset
images.altText: people climbing on boulders are silhouetted against a colorful sunset sky
images.caption: Jumbo Rocks Campground is a fun place to explore the park's bouldered landscape.

images.title: Stars Over the Park Entrance
images.altText: night scene showing stars of the Milky Way over a sign saying "Entering Joshua Tree National Park"
images.caption: Enjoy some of the darkest night skies in Southern California.

weatherInfo: Days are typically clear with less than 25% humidity. Temperatures are most comfortable in the spring and fall, with an average highs around 85Â°F (29Â°C) and average lows around 50Â°F (10Â°C) respectively. Winter brings cooler days, around 60Â°F (15Â°C), and freezing nights. It occasionally snows at higher elevations. Summers are hot, over 100Â°F (38Â°C) during the day and not cooling much below 75Â°F (24Â°C) at night.

description: Huge mountains, rugged foothills, deep canyons, vast caverns, and the worldâs largest trees exemplify the diversity of landscapes, life, and beauty here. Explore these pages to plan your visit or to learn about the plants and animals here and the threats they face. Ancient giant sequoias may seem invincible, but they, too are vulnerable.
wildlife: 21 species of reptiles: 14 snakes, 5 lizards, 1 skink and 1 turtle

entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling in a single vehicle for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This entry fee is for a single person traveling on foot or by bicycle. It is valid for 1-7 days in Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling on a motorcycle, scooter, or similar motorized vehicle for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups traveling in vehicles that have a capacity of up to 15 passengers pay a $35 vehicle entrance fee or use a park pass. Groups traveling in a bus or vehicle with a capacity of 16 persons or more are charged $20 per person, up to the maximums listed for commercial groups with comparable passenger capacity ($100 or $200). People 15 years old or younger, anyone with a pass that may be used for park entry, and drivers hired for transportation only are exempt from the per person fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 7-15 people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 16-25 people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 26 or more people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: The charge for vehicles with a seating capacity of 1-6 passengers is $25, plus $20 per passenger, with a maximum total fee of $75. This entrance fee is for commercial tours of one or more people traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: The per person fee for vehicles with a seating capacity of 1-6 passengers is $20, plus $25 per vehicle, with a maximum total fee of $75. This entrance fee is for commercial tours of one or more people traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake Ranger District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument for one year from the month of purchase. The pass admits all passengers in a private vehicle and is non-transferable.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

directionsInfo: Two highways enter the parks. Hwy 180 from Fresno leads east to Kings Canyon National Park, then continues 30 miles east to Cedar Grove. Hwy 198 from Visalia leads east to Sequoia National Park via Three Rivers. Inside the parks, Highway 198 becomes the Generals Highway, which connects 198 to 180. Vehicles over 22-feet long should enter the parks via Highway 180. In winter, the Generals Highway between the parks often closes. Chains may be required on park roads. No roads cross these parks east to west.

operatingHours.description: The parks are open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Rarely, extreme weather conditions may cause roads into the parks to be closed.
operatingHours.name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks

images.title: Kings Canyon
images.altText: A deep canyon with a forested floor and steep granite cliffs
images.caption: The Glaciers carved the Kings Canyon's steep granite cliffs, leaving a wide U-shaped valley.

images.title: The Tablelands
images.altText: A steep granite slope leads from forest to a bare alpine landscape
images.caption: Just above Lodgepole Valley, the trail to the Watchtower offers views above the treeline.

images.title: Moro Rock
images.altText: A guardrail encircles people along a narrow walkway with wide views
images.caption: A historic stairway leads to the top of Moro Rock, offering views from foothills to peaks

images.title: Giant Sequoia in Winter
images.altText: A giant sequoia's reddish bark contrasts with the snow around it
images.caption: For those who don't mind icy roads, winter offers stunning views of sequoias in snow.

images.title: Giant Forest Museum
images.altText: A rustic building is surrounded by giant sequoias
images.caption: Giant Forest Museum offers exhibits, park information, and a bookstore.

weatherInfo: Because of the extreme elevation range in these parks, weather conditions vary widely between areas. In summer, the sequoia groves have comfortable temperatures and the foothills are hot and dry. Snow lingers on high-mountain passes well into summer. In fall, some areas close or reduce their hours. Winter brings snow to sequoia groves and rain to the foothills. Be prepared for tire chain requirements. Spring is a great time to hike in the foothills and snow begins to melt at higher elevations.

description: Lassen Volcanic National Park is home to steaming fumaroles, meadows freckled with wildflowers, clear mountain lakes, and numerous volcanoes. Jagged peaks tell the story of its eruptive past while hot water continues to shape the land.

entranceFees.description: Valid for up to 7 consecutive days from the day of purchase at Lassen Volcanic National Park. Payable in-person at park entrances. Self-registration when not staffed.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Valid for up to 7 consecutive days at Lassen Volcanic National Park between December 1 and April 15. Payable in-person at park entrances. Self-registration when not staffed.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Valid for one motorcycle regardless of the amount of passengers. Valid for up to 7 consecutive days at Lassen Volcanic National Park. Payable in-person at park entrances. Self-registration when not staffed.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Per person entrance fee for one entry on foot, bicycle, or for individuals traveling together in a vehicle as a non-commercial, organized group. Valid for 7 consecutive days at Lassen Volcanic National Park. Payable in-person at park entrances. Self-registration when not staffed.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: School groups are eligible for a fee waiver. Applicants must prove they are a bona fide academic institution, provide a written statement confirming that the visit supports a specific curriculum for which academic credit is offered, and provide a written statement identifying the park resources and/or facilities that will be used to support the educational purpose of the visit, and how they are relevant to that purpose.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: Valid for up to 7 consecutive days for a vehicle carrying the same group of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees are based upon the total seating capacity of vehicles regardless of the actual number of passengers. Annual or lifetime passes are not accepted.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: Valid for up to 7 consecutive days for a vehicle carrying the same group of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees are based upon the total seating capacity of vehicles regardless of the actual number of passengers. Annual or lifetime passes are not accepted.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: Valid for up to 7 consecutive days for a vehicle carrying the same group of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees are based upon the total seating capacity of vehicles regardless of the actual number of passengers. Annual or lifetime passes are not accepted.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: Valid for up to 7 consecutive days for a vehicle carrying the same group of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees are based upon the total seating capacity of vehicles regardless of the actual number of passengers. Annual or lifetime passes are not accepted.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: Valid for one motorcycle regardless of the amount of passengers. Valid for up to 7 consecutive days at Lassen Volcanic National Park. Payable in-person at park entrances. Self-registration when not staffed.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Per person entrance fee for one entry on foot, bicycle, or for individuals traveling together in a vehicle as a non-commercial, organized group. Valid for 7 consecutive days at Lassen Volcanic National Park. Payable in-person at park entrances. Self-registration when not staffed.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: The Lassen Volcanic Annual Multi-Park Pass is valid for entrance fees at Lassen Volcanic National Park, Whiskeytown National Recreation Area, Crater Lake National Park, or Lava Beds National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

directionsInfo: From Interstate 5 (Redding), take Hwy 44 - 48 miles east to the junction of Hwy 89. Follow Hwy 89 south 1 mile to the north entrance of the park. From Interstate 5 (Red Bluff) take Hwy 36 E - 51 miles east to the junction of Hwy 89. Follow Hwy 89 north 6 miles to south entrance of the park.

operatingHours.description: The park is always open. Road access is limited during the winter season, approximately November through May, due to snow.
operatingHours.name: Entire park, all entrances

images.title: Winter at Manzanita Lake
images.altText: A frozen lake below snow-covered trees and peak
images.caption: With over 30 feet of snowfall annually, Lassen provides numerous opportunities for winter recreation.

images.title: Hat Creek
images.altText: Golden grasses edge a pond reflecting a snow-dusted peak
images.caption: Lassen Volcanic's rugged volcanic landscape is softened by numerous meadows, lakes, and creeks.

images.title: Bumpass Hell
images.altText: A boardwalk passes through a colorful, steaming hydrothermal basin.
images.caption: A 3-mile round-trip trail leads to Bumpass Hell, the largest of the park's hydrothermal areas.

images.title: Brokeoff Panorama
images.altText: Two hikers sit on a mountain top with a view of multiple peaks, dotted with patches of snow
images.caption: Over 150 miles of trails let you choose your adventure.

images.title: Deep Blue
images.altText: A volcanic peak rises above a tree-lined, deep blue lake.
images.caption: Lassen Peak stands out boldly between the bright blue sky and the sapphire hue of Lake Helen.

images.title: A Fisherman's Paradise
images.altText: A fisherman casts a line from a boat below a snow-dotted volcanic peak.
images.caption: Manzanita Lake offers spectacular catch-and-release fishing in the shadow of volcanoes.

images.title: Lassen Peak Eruption
images.altText: An ash cloud rises above a volcano with an early 19th century vehicle at the forefront.
images.caption: A large, explosive eruption of Lassen Peak brought national attention and set the stage for the establishment of Lassen Peak.

weatherInfo: Weather at Lassen can vary dramatically throughout the year. Average January temperatures are a high of 40.4 Â°F (4.7 Â°C) and a low of 20.8 Â°F (-6.2 Â°C). Average July temperatures are a high of 88.4 Â°F and a low of 49.8 Â°F. Temperatures reach 90 Â°F or higher on an average of 36.9 days, and drop to 32 Â° or lower on an average of 164 days days annually.

description: Some 23 million years ago multiple volcanoes erupted, flowed, and slid to form what would become Pinnacles National Park. What remains is a unique landscape. Travelers journey through chaparral, oak woodlands, and canyon bottoms. Hikers enter rare talus caves and emerge to towering rock spires teeming with life: prairie and peregrine falcons, golden eagles, and the inspiring California condor.

entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling in a single vehicle to Pinnacles East Entrance and West Entrance.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling on a motorcycle, scooter, or similar motorized vehicle to Pinnacles East Entrance and West Entrance.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This entry fee is for a single person traveling on foot or by bicycle.  It is valid for 1-7 days to Pinnacles East Entrance and West Entrance.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups traveling in vehicles that have a capacity of 16 passengers or more pay $15 per person up to the maximums listed for commercial groups with comparable passenger capacity ($40 or $100). People 15 years old or younger, anyone with a pass that may be used for park entry, and drivers hired for transportation only are exempt from the per person fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: The charge for vehicles with a seating capacity of 1-6 passengers is $30. This entrance fee is for commercial tours of one or more people traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 7-15 people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational puposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passengers ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial trous of vehicles with a seating capacity of 16-25 people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the sevice. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passengers ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 26 or more people that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for 12 months from the month of purchase. It covers the entrance fee to Pinnacles National Park for the pass signee and accompanying passengers entering in a single, non-commercial vehicle. Pinnacles Annual Passes are available at park entrance stations and visitor centers.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

directionsInfo: Pinnacles National Park is accessible through highway 101 for the West entrance, and highway 25 for the East entrance. From highway 101 you must pass through the City of Soledad to find highway 146 which will lead to West side of Pinnacles. To enter East Pinnacles you must find highway 25 through the City of Hollister coming from the North, and King City through Bitter Water Road (G-13) when coming from the South. NOTE: There is no through road between the east and west entrance.

operatingHours.description: Entrance to the east side of Pinnacles National Park is open 24 hours, 7 days a week, including holidays.
operatingHours.name: East Side Entrance

operatingHours.description: The west entrance to the park offers access to trails such as Prewett Point, Balconies, and Juniper Canyon. Note: this one-lane road is narrow and winding. Oversize vehicles should enter the park on the east side.
operatingHours.name: West Side Entrance

images.title: Balconies Caves
images.altText: Boulders in the Balconies Cave.
images.caption: Balconies Cliffs as seen from the inside of the Balconies Caves

images.title: Tree
images.altText: Light falling on tree
images.caption: Light illuminates a tree on a rainy day, seen from the Resurrection Wall.

images.title: Tarantula
images.altText: A Tarantula walking
images.caption: A Tarantula crawls in the wild.

images.title: High Peaks with Condors Above
images.altText: A massive rock spire with California condors flying above the peak.
images.caption: The best views of Pinnacles' rocks can be enjoyed from the west side with almost no effort required.

weatherInfo: Pinnacles National Park has a Mediterranean climate with hot, dry summers, and mild winters with moderate precipitation. The park is several miles inland from the Pacific Ocean. A wider variation in seasonal temperatures can be expected in the local area. Summers are hot with temperatures above 100 degrees. Winters are cooler with highs in the 60s. Big swings in temperature occur between day and night, year round.

description: Most people know Redwood as home to the tallest trees on Earth. But the Park also protect vast prairies, oak woodlands, wild rivers, and 40 miles of rugged coastline. People have lived in this verdant landscape since time immemorial. Together, the National Park Service and California State Parks are managing and restoring these lands for the inspiration, enjoyment, and education of all.
directionsInfo: Redwood National and State Parks is located in northernmost coastal California - almost on the Oregon border. The parks are about 60-miles long, with four visitor centers from north to south. We are a six to seven-hour drive (325 miles) north of San Francisco, a six-hour drive (330 miles) south of Portland, OR and a four-hour drive (170 miles) west of Redding, CA.

operatingHours.description:
The national and state parks are always open to enjoy. 
Roads, trails and public access remain open year round.

Some campgrounds and visitor centers are closed - or have reduced hours - in the off-season (October-May)
operatingHours.name: Operating Hours

images.title: Fish-eye view of Redwood canopy
images.altText: View from forest floor looking straight up. Ferns as seen close up and redwood trunks meet.
images.caption: The redwood forest is a complicated and beautiful series of habitats.

images.title: Visitors Plan Their Redwood Trip
images.altText: Five young women read the park map.
images.caption: A great redwood trip starts with good trip planning.

images.title: Howland Hill Road
images.altText: Redwood trees line a narrow dirt road.
images.caption: With a small car, you can expericne close-up Redwoods along a century old, narrow road.

images.title: Tide pooling at Enderts Beach
images.altText: Two visitors looking at tidepools.
images.caption: We have forty miles of coastline to explore.

images.title: Ranger Program at Klamath River Overlook
images.altText: Visitors chatting with a ranger above a river mouth.
images.caption: Coastal overlooks provide amazing places to whale watch.. and more.

images.title: Visitors on walkway to Lady Bird Johnson Grove
images.altText: Three people stand on a walkway in the trees. It is foggy.
images.caption: Visitors to the Lady Bird Johnson Grove cross a road using a walkway.

images.title: Family Enjoys the Redwoods
images.altText: Two adults and child look upwards into a forest
images.caption: Millions of people visit the park to enjoy the forests.

images.title: A New Junior Ranger
images.altText: A ranger helps a father and son learn about being a junior ranger.
images.caption: Becoming a junior ranger at Redwoods is a fun and educational for the whole family.

images.title: "Big Tree" wayside.
images.altText: Visitors pose with one of the widest Redwood trees.
images.caption: For those short of time, the "Big Tree" offers easy access for all to a very photogenic tree.

images.title: Incoming Tide at  Redwood National Park
images.altText: Rocks, rockpools and waves
images.caption: 40 miles of coastline are part of Redwood National Park

images.title: Nurse log on the side of a trail.
images.altText: A tree stump is covered with plants.
images.caption: A fallen redwood tree will be on the forest floor for centuries providing habitat for a new generation of plants and animals.

images.title: Ranger and Visitors in the Redwoods
images.altText: Two adults talk with a park ranger under foggy trees
images.caption: Park rangers help visitor learn about and safely enjoy the Redwoods.

images.title: Trillium Falls
images.altText: A small waterfall cascades past different trees
images.caption: The Trillium Falls Trail is a popular, easy and family friendly walk.

images.title: How Tall is that Redwood?
images.altText: Three adults stand and look curiously toward the tree tops
images.caption: From the forest floor we can only see about a third of any old redwood tree.

images.title: How wide is that Redwood?
images.altText: Two adults and a child stand next to a tree while a ranger nearby opens his arms wide.
images.caption: The height and size of redwood trees can be hard to measure.

images.title: Having fun under the redwoods
images.altText: Four adults stand on a trail surrounded by redwood trees
images.caption: Taking a walk on the trail through redwood groves is great fun

images.title: Redwood Ranger in the mist
images.altText: Fog surrounds tall redwoods on a trail. A park ranger stands in the distance.
images.caption: Park Rangers help tell the stories and meanings of the park to visitors.

images.title: Tall Trees Grove from the creek
images.altText: Gray cobbles on the foreground and 300foot redwoods behind.
images.caption: 300 foot redwood redwoods next to Redwood Creek.

images.title: Footbridge to Lady Bird Johnson Grove
images.altText: A footbridge with people crosses a road on a foggy day
images.caption: Summer fog is frequent in the redwoods

images.title: A family walks in Stout Grove
images.altText: A trail meanders into a  grove of tall trees. A family is seen  at the far end of the trail.
images.caption: Redwood forests are wonderful places to walk, relax and look up.

images.title: Coastline at Redwood National Park
images.altText: Waves run-up on a beach, and sea stack rocks are seen in the distance.
images.caption: 40 miles of protected coastline are part of Redwood National and State Parks

images.title: Fern Canyon
images.altText: Green ferns cover two natural walls cut by a creek. A calm creek is covered with grey cobbles.
images.caption: Fern Canyon is a popular - and busy - summer desination.

images.title: A Redwood Grove
images.altText: Reddy-brown colored redwoods
images.caption: Over a hundred miles of trails lead you to places like this.

images.title: Autumn Colors in the redwood parks
images.altText: A trail underneath trees with orange and yellow leaves
images.caption: Big leaf maples in the autumn.

images.title: Fire scarred giants
images.altText: A circle of redwood trees with black fire scars.
images.caption: Fire has always been a part of a redwood tree's history.

images.title: Redwoods Resprouting
images.altText: Young redwood sprouts grow off a horizontal redwood log
images.caption: New shoots grow off a fallen redwood tree.

images.title: Trillium Falls Trail
images.altText: A trail and bridge crosses a tree-line gully.
images.caption: A short walk leads visitors to a series of small cascades.

images.title: Surrounded by old-growth redwoods.
images.altText: A visitor stands next to a forest of enormous red and brown colored trees.
images.caption: Walking though redwood forests is a beautiful experience.

images.title: Autumn leaves in the redwood parks
images.altText: Orange and red leaves on maple trees.
images.caption: Maples and oak trees show fall colors in the redwood parks.

images.title: Enderts Beach
images.altText: Rugged coastal cliffs drop to blue ocean and waves. Pink flowers in the foreground.
images.caption: The park protects forty miles of rugged coastline and marine protected areas..

weatherInfo: Visitors should be prepared for cooler and damp weather. Dress in layers and expect to get wet. Year-round temperatures along California's redwood coast: mid-40sÂ°F (7Â°C) to mid-60sÂ°F (18Â°C). Summer can be foggy, with highs occasionally reaching low 70sÂ°F (20Â°C). Winters are cooler with considerable rain. October through April averages 60-80 inches of rain over the region.

description: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra. First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.
wildlife: 22 species of reptiles: 13 snakes, 7 lizards, 1 skink and 1 turtle

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days for a non-commercial car, pickup truck, RV, or van with 15 or fewer passenger seats. This fee covers the vehicle and everyone inside of it.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days for a non-commercial motorcycle (cost is per motorcycle, not person).
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days for people entering on foot, a bicycle, a horse, or a non-commercial bus or van. People 15 years and younger are free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: The fee is $25 plus $20 per person, not to exceed $105. This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. People 15 years and younger are free
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: An educational fee waiver is available for educational and scientific groups that are accredited or tax-exempt for educational purposes planning a trip for educational or scientific purposes related to Yosemite that is not primarily recreational.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: The fee is $25 plus $20 per person, not to exceed $105. This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance to Yosemite for 12 months from the date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

directionsInfo: You can drive to Yosemite year-round and enter via Highways 41, 140, and 120 from the west. Tioga Pass Entrance (via Highway 120 from the east) is closed from approximately November through late May or June. Hetch Hetchy is open all year but may close intermittently due to snow. Please note that GPS units do not always provide accurate directions to or within Yosemite.

operatingHours.description: Yosemite National Park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.
operatingHours.name: Yosemite National Park

images.title: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.altText: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring

images.title: Yosemite Valley from Tunnel View
images.altText: Glaciated valley with vertical cliffs.
images.caption: Tunnel View is perhaps one of the most photographed views in the park.

images.title: Rainbow over Half Dome
images.altText: A rainbow over a mountain in the distance.
images.caption: A hike up to Sentinel Dome rewards people with great views of the landscape around them.

images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.
images.caption: Cathedral Peak is one of the most recognizable peaks in the Yosemite Wilderness.

images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.altText: A waterfall flowing down a granite cliff.
images.caption: The walk to Lower Yosemite Fall is a popular and easy hike.

images.title: Yosemite Falls on a Winter Morning
images.altText: Two tall waterfalls flowing down snow covered granite walls.
images.caption: Yosemite Falls will sometimes only trickle at the end of summer, but wet winters can rejuvenate the flow.

images.title: Glen Aulin
images.altText: Mountains reflecting in water
images.caption: Glen Auilin is one of five High Sierra Camps, located in the Yosemite high country.

images.title: Giant Sequoia Trees in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
images.altText: Cluster of tall trees with cloudy sky.
images.caption: Yosemite National Park's massive giant sequoias (Sequoiadendron giganteum) live in three groves in the park. The most famous of these is the Mariposa Grove, which contains about 500 mature giant sequoias.

images.title: Tenaya Lake at Sunset
images.altText: Mountains surrounding a lake.
images.caption: Tenaya Lake is a favorite place to stop along the Tioga Road in summer.

images.title: Half Dome
images.altText: Granite dome with trace amounts of snow.
images.caption: Half Dome is one of the most recognizable granitic formations in the world.

images.title: El Capitan
images.altText: El Capitan and reflection in Merced River with some low clouds
images.caption: El Capitan rises over 3,000 feet above the floor of Yosemite Valley.

images.title: View of Yosemite Valley in Winter
images.altText: El Capitan on left, Cathedral Rocks on the right, all covered in snow, low clouds and sun
images.caption: A rewarding view of Yosemite Valley in winter as seen from Tunnel View.

weatherInfo: Yosemite National Park covers nearly 1,200 square miles (3,100 square km) in the Sierra Nevada, with elevations ranging from about 2,000 feet (600 m) to 13,000 ft (4,000 m). Yosemite receives 95% of its precipitation between October and May (and over 75% between November and March). Most of Yosemite is blanketed in snow from about November through May. (Yosemite Valley can be rainy or snowy in any given winter storm.)
